Title: Northern and Central Mountains
AvalancheSummary: Generally safe avalanche conditions exist. The few areas where you may be able to trigger an avalanche are where about one to three inches of new snow from Thursday, accompanied by strong westerly winds, created thin, cohesive slabs of snow on top of weak October snow. Identify and avoid wind-loaded slopes to reduce your chances of triggering a small but potentially dangerous avalanche. You are most likely to encounter these wind-loaded slopes on the lee sides of a ridgeline or in a northerly or easterly-facing gully or couloir where the snow has a hard, hollow feel to it.

Title: Park Range
AvalancheSummary: New snow on Thursday and continuing wind will keep the avalanche danger elevated above treeline in the Park Range on Friday. You can trigger an avalanche where you find recently drifted snow resting on weak, old snow from October. You are most likely to find this combination on north, northeast, and east-facing slopes, especially just below ridgelines and in gullies. Any avalanche you trigger should be small, but could take you for a ride over exposed rocks.

Title: Southern Mountains
AvalancheSummary: Limited snow cover means there are very few places where you can trigger an avalanche. If you find hard, wind-drifted snow on high-elevation northerly-facing slopes, there is a slim chance you might trigger a small avalanche. Use caution traveling in steep gullies and areas close to ridgelines where going for a ride in a small slide with such shallow snow cover can be dangerous.

Title: Southern Mountains Regional Forecast
Message: Southern Mountains Regional DiscussionOn Thursday, mountain snow showers broke up the steady string of bluebird skies, but did little to change current avalanche conditions. Emerson said…”adopt the pace of nature, her secret is patience”. Backcountry enthusiast hoping for notable change to snow conditions have to wait a tad bit longer. The next shot at meaningful snowfall arrives Saturday afternoon, and places in the San Juan Mountains that do well on southwest flow could see eight or more inches of total snow by Sunday. If this scenario plays out, the avalanche danger could rise to Moderate (2of5) above treeline on slopes where weak, early-season snow lingers.So far this season, we have no reports of avalanche activity in the Southern Mountains. Limited snow cover coincides with little avalanche hazard. Areas near Red Mountain Pass, in the Sneffels Range, and near Ophir have received more snow than areas south of Silverton along US 550, in the La Plata Mountains, near Wolf Creek Pass, and Sangre de Cristo Range. Even in the deepest snowfall areas, the snowpack is thin and discontinuous even on shady slopes. Sunny slopes have mostly melted to bare ground.If you were to find a slope with continuous snow cover, an avalanche you trigger would likely be small. Places that harbor wind-drifted snow over weak, faceted snow may exist on high-elevation, northerly aspects. Weather hiking, hunting, or in search of early-season turns, use caution in steeper terrain where even a small avalanche can lead to a rough, nasty ride over shallowly-buried obstacles.Remember, what snow persist on slopes is rapidly losing cohesion and becoming a weak layer of the future. As we prepare for a change to more wintry weather, noting where the snow has collected and what slopes are bare ground will help you stay ahead of the avalanche curve once winter arrives and the snowpack gains depth. Until then, burn a pair of old skis for Ullr or wash your vehicle to help make it snow.

Title: Northern Mountains Regional Discussion
Message: Northern Mountains Regional DiscussionWith an additional few inches of snowfall and continued wind forecast for Thursday night we kept the danger elevated for the Park Range on Friday. Elsewhere in the North, the danger remains LOW (Level 1 of 5).On high-elevation northerly and some east-facing slopes, weak, faceted snow is still left from October and early November storms. In some places, there are thin slabs of denser, drifted snow above the weak, faceted snow. Whether the surface is soft or hard, the snowpack structure is poor. New snow is drifting and forming slabs that are resting on this poorly structured snowpack. This combination is a recipe for avalanches. You are most likely to trigger an avalanche where October weak layers got buried on Thursday. Thankfully, the weak, old snow is not continuous across the slope. While this should keep the avalanche size small, keep in mind that any ride in an avalanche will likely result in being carried over rocks or other obstacles at this time.The weather breaks on Friday as the next storm starts to make its way to our area Saturday night. No additional precipitation is expected Friday and the danger may briefly go back down to LOW (Level 1 of 5) in the Park Range on Saturday. Any drop in danger will be short-lived as the next system begins to affect the Northern Mountains beginning Saturday night though Monday. Look for favored areas to split off of the large Northern and Central Mountains zone for Sunday and the danger to increase. Many southerly-facing slopes melted back to bare ground in the Northern Mountains during the recent warm and sunny weather. Look to these slopes for safer riding as they get buried over the weekend.

Title: Central Mountains Regional Discussion
Message: Central Mountains Regional DiscussionSome long-awaited snow arrived in the Central Mountains on Thursday, although it wasn’t much. The highest portions of the Grand Mesa and Frying Pan as well as portions of the Sawatch saw up to one or two inches of snow while portions of the Elk and West Elk Mountains picked up about two to four inches of snow. Accompanied by some strong west-to-southwest winds, Thursday's storm did little to change the avalanche danger as not enough snow fell to develop any sort of slab aside from some isolated, wind-loaded terrain features. By avoiding traveling on the lee sides of ridgelines at the top of the slope or in cross-loaded gullies and couloirs, or any other typical wind-loaded terrain features, you can drastically reduce your chances of triggering an avalanche. Any avalanche you trigger will likely be small but they can still take you for a rocky, dangerous ride and entrain any old snow from October growing slightly bigger than you might expect.Tomorrow will be another dry November day across the Central Mountains but this weekend our next storm arrives. Snowfall should start across most of the region on Saturday, increasing in intensity on Sunday. By Monday, favored areas in the West Elks, Elks, and Grand Mesa may see over a foot of total snow. Once we reach about 10 to 12 inches of snow you will see the avalanche danger increase quickly. There is a well-developed weak layer from our October snow storms on most northwest, north, and northeast slopes as well as some high-elevation east and southeast-facing slopes. Once enough snow falls to create a slab on this weak layer you can expect it to be very easy to trigger avalanches on any slopes that had continuous snow coverage prior to Thursday’s snowfall. It is far too early to tell what the winter season will bring, but we know once we get enough snow to develop a slab it will bring several days to several weeks of heightened to dangerous avalanche conditions across a great deal of the Central Mountains.

Title: Northern and Central Mountains
AvalancheSummary: While generally safe avalanche conditions exist, there are some isolated areas where you can trigger an avalanche. Look out for and avoid places where drifting snow formed thin, cohesive slabs that rest on weak October snow. You are most likely to find these areas at high elevations on northerly and east-facing slopes, especially just below ridgelines or in a gully or couloir. Identify and avoid these slopes to reduce your chances of triggering a small but potentially dangerous avalanche.

Title: Northwest San Juan
AvalancheSummary: Most slopes are safe from avalanches, mainly due to thin or non-existent snow cover.  Some welcome snowfall is increasing the threat for avalanches on wind-loaded slopes in the alpine. New and drifting snow means you can find slopes with wind-stiffened snow on high-elevation northerly-facing slopes where you could trigger a small avalanche. Use caution traveling in steep gullies and areas close to ridgelines where going for a ride in a small slide with such shallow snow cover can be dangerous.

Title: Snowy Elks
AvalancheSummary: You can easily trigger small avalanches on steep, wind-loaded slopes facing northwest through north to east, generally above 10,000 ft. These avalanches may be small but they can knock you off your feet and take you for a dangerous ride through a thin snowpack. To reduce your chances of triggering an avalanche avoid traveling on steep slopes where you notice wind drifting snow onto the slope. The most dangerous areas are the lee sides of ridgelines and in gullies or couloirs where wind shifting from the southwest through west to the northwest will continuously load additional snow onto a very weak snowpack.

Title: Park and Flat Top
AvalancheSummary: Snow on Sunday and Monday falls onto weak snow left from October. You can trigger an avalanche where you find recently drifted snow resting on this weak base, especially in areas that held continuous coverage of old weak snow. You are most likely to find this combination at upper elevations on northerly and east-facing slopes, just below ridgelines or in gully features. Avoid these slopes to reduce your chances of triggering a small but potentially dangerous avalanche.

Title: Main San Juan
AvalancheSummary: Most slopes are safe from avalanches, mainly due to thin or non-existent snow cover.  Some new and drifting snow means you might find isolated slopes with wind-stiffened snow on high-elevation northerly-facing slopes where you could trigger a small avalanche. Use caution traveling in steep gullies and areas close to ridgelines where going for a ride in a small slide with such shallow snow cover can be dangerous.

Title: Central Mountains Regional Discussion
Message: Central Mountains Regional DiscussionA notable storm will impact the Central Mountains starting Saturday evening through Monday. The storm starts on a southwest flow shifting to the west promoting a zonal flow that favors the Elk and West Elk Mountains before shifting to the northwest later in the day on Sunday. This storm will start warm under a southwest flow then a cold front arrive Sunday afternoon as the flow shifts northwest quickly decreasing temperatures. This “right-side-up” storm will start warm with wet, dense snow and as temperatures decrease the snow will become colder and less dense. Normally this is a good thing as it decreases the chances for Storm Slab avalanches to develop into a major issue. In this case, the snow will quickly develop into a slab with a dense base on top of an incredibly weak snowpack on almost every slope that holds continuous snow. The weak base to the snowpack from all of our October snow has been rotting under dry weather, low relative humidity, and cold, clear nights for the first half of November. Once a slab develops on this weak layer you can expect it to be very easy to trigger avalanches. The only reason the avalanche danger remains at Moderate (Level 2 of 5) is because the size of these avalanches will likely remain small until the slab builds up quite a bit more.Hopefully, avid backcountry travelers have been taking note of slopes that currently have continuous snow coverage across them. These slopes will be the most dangerous in the coming days as a slab develops on top of an already well-developed weak layer. If you haven’t been paying close attention to snow coverage try looking through the CAIC observations page to see if the slopes you are planning to travel on or near have any images of them from the first half of November. If you have been observing and documenting this snow coverage consider submitting an observation to us even if it is just a short description of the area and a few images!

Title: Southern Mountains Regional Forecast
Message: Southern Mountains Regional DiscussionSome welcome unsettled weather is currently arriving in the Southern Mountains as clouds are increasing and snow begins falling at higher elevations Saturday afternoon. The storm starts out warm with the rain-snow line hovering around 9,500 feet before lowering in elevation on Sunday afternoon. Areas in the San Juan Mountains that do well on southwest flow could see eight or more inches of total snow by Sunday. These are the areas where the avalanche danger will increase to Moderate (Level 2 of 5) above the treeline on slopes where weak, early-season snow lingers. As new snow depths increase, the potential size of the avalanche you could trigger is likely to increase as well.No avalanches were reported throughout the Southern Mountains so far this season highlighting the generally shallow and discontinuous snow coverage we currently have. For the most part, the new snow Saturday through Monday will be falling on the ground or slopes with discontinuous snow coverage basically building our snowpack from scratch. This could be a good thing depending on what the next few weeks bring as we could have a significantly less widespread weak layer than parts of the Central and Northern Mountains.Hopefully, avid backcountry travelers have been taking note of slopes that currently have continuous snow coverage across them. These slopes will be the most dangerous in the coming days as a slab develops on top of an already well-developed weak layer. If you haven’t been paying close attention to snow coverage try looking through the CAIC observations page to see if the slopes you are planning to travel on or near have any images of them from the first half of November. If you have been observing and documenting this snow coverage consider submitting an observation to us even if it is just a short description of the area and a few images!

Title: Northern Mountains Regional Discussion
Message: Northern Mountains Regional DiscussionModels have decreased snowfall totals for the Northern Mountains as the storm arrives. Favored areas should see about 10 inches of snow with most areas in the four to eight inch range by Monday evening. Snow starts Saturday night in favored areas and lasts through Monday across the region. The Park Range, and to a lesser extent the Flat Tops, are still forecast to be the big winners with this storm and should see most of their accumulation on the front end of this system. Areas further to the east, like the Front Range and Summit County, see more intense snowfall on Sunday and Sunday night as the wind shifts to the north.In areas where snow begins tonight, like the Park Range and Flat Tops, the danger increases to MODERATE (Level 2 of 5) on Sunday. Across the Northern Mountains, snow is falling on weak, faceted snow from October and early November that was left on high-elevation northerly and east-facing slopes. Westerly winds will drift the new snow onto this weak base and avalanche conditions will become more dangerous quickly. Thankfully, the weak, old snow was generally confined to gully features and just below ridgelines was not very continuous across the slope. This should keep the overall avalanche size small and it is unlikely we’ll see enough snow to move beyond MODERATE (Level 2 of 5) danger.In the rest of the Northern Mountains, peak snowfall is focused more on Sunday and Sunday night. While snow totals likely won’t be high enough to raise the avalanche danger, we may add a Wind Slab avalanche problem given a widespread few inches of snow with wind. The Flat Tops may fall into this lower danger category, check back tomorrow morning to see if that area stays with the Park Range or joins the rest of the Northern Mountains. If tomorrow’s forecasts begin to increase totals for the rest of the Northern Mountains, there may be a bump in danger on Monday - although this scenario seems unlikely at this time. Areas like Cameron Pass and the Gore Range are the most likely places to see higher totals than the rest of the Front Range and Summit County areas.Keep in mind that there are still early-season conditions in the Northern Mountains and any ride in an avalanche will likely result in being carried over rocks or other obstacles. Use caution around any drifted pillows of snow you suspect are resting on weak October snow. Cracking within the new snow is an obvious sign of unstable snow and an indication to move to low-angle or wind-sheltered slopes. Many southerly-facing slopes melted back to bare ground in the Northern Mountains during the recent warm and sunny weather. Look to these slopes for safer riding as they begin to get buried.

Title: S Mtns
AvalancheSummary: You can trigger a small avalanche on a steep slope or couloir if you observe more than six inches of new or drifted snow. Northerly slopes are the most dangerous as they harbored early-season snow before this past storm. Identify and avoid slopes steeper than around 35 degrees that appear smooth and rounded. Even a small avalanche can be dangerous in early-season conditions.

Title: Park and Flat Top
AvalancheSummary: You can trigger a small avalanche where you find more than about six inches of new or wind-drifted snow. Look for and avoid textured snow that feels firm under you or cracks beneath your weight. Northerly and east-facing slopes that held snow previous to the weekend's storm will be the most dangerous. Safer riding conditions will be low-angled slopes or those sheltered from the wind.

Title: Northern and Central Mountains
AvalancheSummary: Although unlikely, you could trigger a small avalanche where you find continuous snow, especially if it has more than about six inches of new or wind-drifted snow. This will be more likely close to ridgelines and in shady gully features. If you find rounded pillows of snow that crack beneath you, retreat to lower-angled slopes or those sheltered from the wind.

Title: GM thru Elks2
AvalancheSummary: You can trigger an avalanche where you find more than around 10 inches of recently fallen storm snow on northerly or easterly-facing slopes above around 10,500 feet. Most avalanches will break around a foot deep, although one could break deeper in wind-drifted terrain features. While relatively thin, one of these avalanches could break wider than you might expect. Taking a ride in any avalanche at this time of year could end badly if it pushes you into logs or rocks.Safer travel options include low-angle slopes and terrain where the storm snow fell on dirt.

Title: Northern Mountains Regional Discussion
Message: Northern Mountains Regional DiscussionOver the weekend, a storm hit the region, but it moved out on Monday. The Northern Mountains welcomed a sign of winter. However, most areas needed more snow to change the avalanche danger. Cameron Pass through Berthoud Pass to the Ten Mile Range received between two to six inches of snow, and the avalanche danger remains LOW in these areas. On the other hand, the Park Range received between eight to twelve inches of snow, and the new snow and winds created drifted snow at upper elevations on northerly and east-facing slopes, heightening the avalanche danger toCurrently, high-elevation northerlies and east-facing slopes are presenting problems due to the snow that has been accumulating since October and early November. The warm daytime temperatures of the last two weeks and cold nights created a faceted layer of snow. In the largest cluster of the Northern Mountains stretching from Cameron Pass through Berthoud Pass to the Ten Mile Range, more than the two to six inches of new snow was needed to create a widespread problem. However, there are still a few places that may pose a problem. Observers reported problematic slopes around Rocky Mountain National Park and Jones Pass over the weekend. These terrain features are located along the lee sides of ridges, gullies, couloirs, or avalanche chutes. It's worth noting that Wind Slab avalanches have also been added to this region but are still difficult to trigger.The story is similar to the Park Range, with northerly and east-facing slopes being the most problematic due to the lack of snow in November with the warm days and cold nights. The only difference is the amount of snow they receive over the weekend. The sheer amount of new snow and winds will more easily overload the weak layer, creating a more sensitive trigger for avalanches. These avalanches may still be small, but consider the consequences of the terrain below. Much of the near and below treeline terrain around the Park Range does not have snow on the ground or only a few inches.Outdoor enthusiasts who enjoy activities like hunting, hiking, ice climbing, or sliding on snow should be mindful of the risk of avalanches in their recreational areas. If you notice that the snow starts to support your weight and sounds hollow, you likely stumbled upon a problematic area. Even a small avalanche can have severe consequences. Therefore, it is essential to exercise caution and remain aware of the potential risks involved.

Title: Southern Mountains Regional Forecast
Message: Southern Mountains Regional DiscussionThe storm arrived warm on Saturday, and snow was slow to accumulate. Precipitation intensity picked up on Sunday afternoon and continued into Monday. The heaviest snowfall for most of the forecast area was sundown Sunday into Monday morning. Snowfall favored areas around Telluride, Red Mountain Pass, Sneffels Range, and La Plata Mountains. All these areas picked up around a foot of new snow throughout the storm. Areas near Wolf Creek Pass, Molas, Coal Bank, and Sangre de Cristos received a maximum of 4"-6". The snow came in "right-side-up" with denser snow on the bottom and lighter snow on the top. This could help make for a good base but also facet quickly under the forecast weather over the next few days.North winds following the storm are strong enough to move snow and build slabs. The good news is there is little hazard on southerly slopes, so the winds will continue to erode and press north slopes while loading new snow onto bare ground. That said, look for and avoid cross-loaded areas and be wary of stiff surfaces on north slopes.On many slopes, the new snow falls on bare ground, and there isn't enough snow depth to worry about avalanches. The exception is high northerly-facing slopes and gullies that held early-season snow for most of November. On these slopes, weak faceted snow sits below the recent snowfall. You can trigger avalanches on steep slopes where you find more than six inches of fresh snow with old snow below. If you are out recreating on snow and find a nice snow-covered slope, dig down to see what is under the blanket of white. Avoid traveling on slopes if you find weak snow under a freshly built slab. In the parts of the forecast area that picked up around a foot of snow, the avalanche hazard and size of the avalanche you can trigger are more significant than in areas that only picked up a few inches from this past storm.Tuesday, looks like the return of warm and dry weather, which will continue into the Thanksgiving holiday before snow returns for the end of the week and into the weekend.

Title: Copy of Central Mountains Regional Discussion
Message: Central Mountains Regional DiscussionA decent, and much-welcomed, storm brought 8 to 12 inches of storm snow to the Grand Mesa and Elk Mountains. This new load brought with it an uptick in the size of avalanches and a change of problem from Wind Slab to Persistent Slab avalanches. In the Elk Mountains, there is a  facet crust combination that formed during warm clear weather earlier in the month and is now buried under about 1 foot of storm snow.  Observers in Marble and close to Aspen have recently reported larger avalanches with propagation across whole terrain features. The crust is supporting the weight of the new snow and allows wide propagation with the weak facets above and below despite a relatively soft slab above. This change is the reason we made the problem switch to Persistent Slab avalanches. Let's all hope they don’t stay with us for the rest of the season. As the slab gains more strength and continuity we can expect to start seeing avalanches being triggered from below and remotely. This problem can not be managed through ski cuts or simple assessment of the snow surface as they can potentially break well above you.  The rest of the Central Mountains only picked up 1 to 4 inches of snow and had less continuous snow coverage prior to the storm. Here you can still find isolated wind-drifted slabs in the alpine, but most slopes are safe from avalanches due to discontinuous snow coverage. Northerly winds over the next few days will further reduce these slabs on northerly aspects and drift snow onto dry southerly slopes. The snow in these areas is very weak so once we finally get a decent storm laying down a slab the avalanche danger will rise quickly.If you have been observing and documenting this snow coverage considersubmitting an observation to us even if it is just a short description of the area and a few images!
